1.content:
"Hey James!! Quit daydreaming man!" yelled a slightly annoyed male voice. It was coming from a young male, about 21 years of age. It was directed at another boy, similarly aged. That boy turned around, sheepishly smiling as he did.

"Sorry man. Guess I let my daydreaming get the best of me" said the boy, chuckling as he did, getting a sigh from the other boy. A girl that was also with the two of them gently giggled.

"Seriously James! You're always such a daydreamer!" said Nate Wilson. He always had to wake up his childhood friend, James Walker, from his constant daydreaming. While it annoyed him somewhat, Erin Wilson, Nate's twin who was the girl of the group, found it to be one of James' best qualities. The sky was the limit for James. That's what she always thought.

James Walker, the man in question, had always been obsessed with dreams of flying. As a young boy, he always watched birds and how they were free to soar through the skies and explore to their hearts' content. He also saw pilots go up in planes, jets, and all kinds of other aircrafts. He could only imagine the joy that came with flying through the air. To him, it felt like freedom. Freedom to go anywhere he wanted and explore new places. It was to that end that he was attending college and would probably soon begin a pilot's class nearby. It would likely start the next semester.

'If only I had wings' thought James. He chuckled at the thought, as he saw the naivety of it all. That could never happen so he had to settle for learning to be a pilot. Anyway, it was close to the end of another springsday for the trio of friends. The sun was beginning to set and they had to head for their separate homes.

"Now don't sleep in tomorrow! We're getting to the beach bright and early, right?" said Nate, his usual enthusiasm showing itself, earning a laugh from the other members of the group.

"Sure thing buddy. You both take care now" said James as he gave Nate their usual hand shake. Erin hugged him as they went their separate ways. As James watched his two friends leave, he couldn't help but feel that he might not see them again for a long time.

"Must be my imagination" muttered James as he began to walk in the direction of his house. For a while, it was a peaceful walk. Not many people out, and things were pretty quiet. James liked the quiet. However, it was interrupted when he started hearing metal clashing in a nearby alley. It sounded like trash cans being tossed around.

"What the hell?" asked James as he slowly walked towards the alley and reeped along the edge, trying to get a good look at the situation. However, nothing could have prepared him for what he saw once he slowly looked around the corner.

"What the-..."

There were four people there: three guys and a girl. There was something off and creepy about the guys, as they walked and swayed like men posessed. However, that wasn't the surprising part. It was the girl. She had dark hair which almost had traces of indigo in the feint light. She wore what looked like a loose-fitting navy tank top with what looked like a matching, feathered skort. She also wore a red sash around her waist. On her feet looked to be simple brown boots that covered her feet and calves. However, despite the beauty that seemed to radiate from the girl, it was something else that grabbed James' attention.

The reason why? On her back, shining radiantly through the emerging darkness of the evening, was a glowing pair of wings.

Radiant and bird-like in shape, her wings gave a soft glow that seemed to warm James even from this distance from her. Primarily, they were a combination of white and lavender colors, emiting an otherworldly presence.

'Who, or what, is she?' James thought in his mind. At first, he must have thought that he was dreaming, or that he finally jumped off the deep end. However, after even pinching himself to try and 'wake up', the girl and guys were still there. However, once James was able to come to terms that they were real, he paied attention to what they were doing. The guys seemed to be gathered around the girl, and James didn't like the look in their eyes.

"Heh heh, a pretty one tonight. I figure those wings of yours may make a good meal" chuckled one man. The other two guys laughed as well as the girl seemed to buckle under their gaze.

"I-I'm not afraid of you. Release those humans at once!" said the girl, stuttering a bit as she did. James had no idea what she meant by her words but he could tell that she was scared. The men didn't believe her words and laughed more. Regardless of how odd James found the girl, he didn't like the thought of guys ganging on a poor girl. He had to take action!

"Hey bozos! Pick on somebody your own size!" said James as he rushed in and knocked one man into a nearby trash can. One of the other guys tried to tackle James but he dodged him and twisted his arms behind his back, making the man yell in pain. He then threw the man onto the one who was allready knocked out.

"Heh, all bark and no bite" said James. However, he was in for a shock as a black shadow started to emerge from the men's mouths, hissing at James as they did. He suddently felt very uncomfortable as he was dealing with things beyond his comprehension. He had to get the girl, who was watching the whole thing in shock, and get away from here.

"You!" he yelled, gesturing to the fear-striken girl. "Come with m.." he said before a cold and painful feeling feeling came from his chest. Looking to the side, he had forgotten about the third man, who had just shot him. In a second, James collasped to the ground.

'Guess I...got in..over my...head' thought James as he felt his life bleeding away.

"NOOO!" yelled the girl who watched her fallen hero hit the ground, barely alive for now. His heart and lungs were untouched but the massive wound would surely cause him to bleed to death. His eyesight already blurring as he felt his life start to bleed away. Then, he heard a loud and commanding voice.

"Attack! Restrain those men!' yelled the voice, which sounded female. It was hard to tell for James due to his blurring eyesight, but two figures suddenly showed up and took down the remaining man and retrieved the other two. There was a burst of light and the shadows seemed to fully burst out of the mean and dissappear. The bodies collasped, unconscious but finally free of the shadows that haunted them.

'Who......are......they?' thought James as he laid there, finally passing out due to blood loss.
1.title: Saving an Angel

11.content:
James awoke nearly an hour later to find himself in a sitting position surrounded by a bright but soft light. A light moan escaped his lips, feeling a bit weak and dizzy but otherwise well. Slowly, his memory returned to him and he recalled being shot, trying to save a winged girl from three men who were attacking her. James shed a single tear, thinking about the young girl and wondered if she was safe. As his eyes became accustomed to the light, he looked up to see a strange vaulted ceiling.

"Where am I?" he weakly asked, aloud.

http://www.freefoto.com/images/46/01/46_...

James tried to move but his body was slow to respond. A hand gently touched his shoulder and guided him to a position where he looked down and gasped, becoming fully awake. "What!?..."

http://media-cdn.tripadvisor.com/media/p...

James pushed himself back, away from the edge of the bed he was sitting on, panic clear on his face until he heard a a giggle, followed by a familiar feminine voice. "Be at peace, young Misterian." she said. "Although you can see down to the Earth, I assure you that there is a solid floor between you and the sky."

James, still alarmed, looked up to see the young winged girl he had tried to rescue, standing on what seemed to be a thick glass surface. Seeing his reluctance, the girl smiled kindly at him before urging him to stand. He did so, hesitantly and was relieved that there was indeed a floor holding him up. "Misterian?" you asked confused. "Am I dead, is this heaven or...?"

The girl laughed, it was sweet and melodious. "No, you are not dead and this is not what you call heaven." she replied. "My name is Myrrh, crown princess to the kingdom of Skyaira." she blushed slightly. "Thank you for coming to my rescue, my mother and I are most grateful."

"You're welcome." replied James, still in a bit of shock. "I... seem to recall being shot."

Myrrh nodded. "You were bleeding very badly." she replied. "There was little time, you were very close to death, my mother performed an induction ritual."

"What is that?" asked James.

Myrrh sighed. "It's complicated but, basically, she used a part of her own life force to rebuild or reshape your body." she explained. "You are now one of us, a young Misterian." she then winced. "Only, there is a certain randomness involved in which mom had no control over."

"Randomness?" asked James, his head beginning to spin.

Myrrh nodded and motioned to a reflective portion of the wall. "You may want to prepare yourself." she said.

Shaking, James looked into the mirror and screamed as he saw that he was now...
11.title: New Awakening

111.content:
The person in the mirror definitely wasn't him! The other young man which stood before him carried zero resemblance to him. He was... gorgeous. That was the best word to describe it. His fair complexion was flawless, his body shape was desirably slim and tall, his features were sharp and... superior in some way. James thought back about the vampires, the beautiful ones from Twilight, and wondered if this guy was a vampire.

Then James noticed the other young man's pair of silver wings, and all thoughts of vampirism fled him.

"Hey," James greeted the amazing young man. "What's.. your name?"

Myrrh hesitated before putting a hand on him sympathetically. She understood the shock involved. "That is you, young Misterian."

"Me...?" James stammered in disbelief. "That can't be..."

"Look again."

He did as he was told, staring back at his reflection in silent wonderment. And after close inspection, James realized that what was similar between this model of a young man and himself was their distinct eye and hair colour - both of which had been James pride and joy. The model's eyes were filled with intense sea blue colour, and his hair painted bright strawberry blond.

James waved at the model in the mirror, only to have the model wave back.

It was him, after all.

"See?" Myrrh said, as though having read his mind. "The result of the induction ritual wasn't so bad after all."

James smiled weakly. "Yeah, at least I'm still somewhat guy. Could've come out female, right?" He joked.

"Precisely," Myrrh replied seriously. "My mother, she... She is not very good at the Induction ritual. And unlike other Misterians, she has little control over the gender of a person. We had to take the chance though."

James breathed a sigh of relief as he stole another glance at his reflection. He didn't want Myrrh to think him vain or anything, but the image of himself was truly breathtaking. Despite being slightly feminine, he still was recognizably a guy.

A gentle tap on his shoulder jolted him from his thoughts.

"You are a young Misterian now," Myrrh said quietly. "Welcome to the Kingdom of Skyaira."

"Oh," James blinked. "That's cool. Thanks... But, how about Earth? How about my family and friends there...?"

Myrrh suddenly looked sad, her beautiful eyes downcast as she spoke softly. "Sorry, but we don't go down to the Earth just for pleasant trips. I believe you should just leave that world behind you."

"What?" James asked in shock. "Can I at least say bye to them? I mean... I just disappeared like that... They'd miss me you see..."

He could feel the tears now, welling up in his eyes, and streaming down his face. He realized then how much he missed them. He remembered his mother and father, how on the morning on the day of his disappearance, had handmade his favourite blueberry pancake for breakfast. And his best friend, Nate. Below all that badass personality, truly cared for James. He would be the one that definitely cried buckets if James wasn't found. And then Erin. The frequent side way looks which she casted at him when he wasn't looking showed her care in him. She wouldn't be too happy if he disappeared too.

"There is... a way." Myrrh was apparently deep in thought now, trying to help James out after seeing that display of tears.

James looked to her excitedly. "What?"

"There are two, actually. One through Quests, and the other through... a test."

"Why can't we just fly down to Earth whenever we want to?" James asked.

Myrrh laughed at this, the sound of her laughter resembling the chimes of a church bell. She shook her head. "Young Misterian, you have much to learn," she laughed again. "We have to control the influx. If millions of winged people flew down to Earth at one go, the humans will freak."

His spirits fell. So what was it again? Quests or Tests?

"Quests are definitely out," Myrrh suggested helpfully

"Why?"

"New Misterians are not applicable for it... You have to be a hundred years of age at the very least." She trailed off. "I was on a quest that day you saved me," she flushed. "I... failed it miserably."

James found himself reaching for her hand to comfort her unconsciously. "It's alright."

"Perhaps, but it is a disgrace to fail one," Myrrh sighed. "Anyway, back on track, you may have to enter the Tests."

"The Tests?"

Myrrh nodded, looking solemn once more. "Every year, new Misterians arrive on Skyaira. Since only a few can return to Earth at one go, including those on Quests, we have implemented a series of Tests for those New Earth-Born Misterians."

Man, this Misterian infested place called Skyaira was getting more complicated by the second.

"Are you Earth-Born?" James couldn't help but ask.

Myrrh shook her head. "No," she replied. "Born and bred on Skyaira like many of the others."

"Oh."

Myrrh continued with the explaining. "The handful of Earth-Born Misterians who win the Tests, are allowed a day to visit Earth. Either to recall old times, visit loved ones, anything. Just one day."

James perked up immediately, feeling an adrenalin rush through him. "I'm gonna win it, Myrrh! I have to!"

She smiled, but this time, the smile didn't reach her eyes. "I hope so," she said, before hesitating. "But... it will not be easy."

"So what is the Tests all about?" James asked with curiosity. He had to win it. He had to win a ticket to Earth. Maybe it wouldn't be easy, but he was born for flight even as a mortal. And don't forget, he had a pair of lovely wings now. He could conquer anything.

Myrrh suddenly grew very uncomfortable. "It is...
111.title: A young winged man.

1113.content:
Myrrh never finished her sentence. Whatever the terrible test consisted of, James would never know. Maybe it was a slaying a fire breathing dragon, or flying to the blazing sun, or fighting a million Earth-Born Misterians, but it was interrupted by an elegant lady Mysterian by the doorway.

"My daughter!" The lady snapped. "It is forbidden to speak of! You know that yourself! It would be injustice for one Earth-Born to know of it when a hundred others remain ignorant!"

"Mother," Myrrh swept herself into a humble curtsy. "You misjudge me, I would never dare to speak of it."

The aristocratic lady pursed her lips thoughtfully, then dismissing it, she turned to James instead.

"And you, brave young Misterian, we will always be in debt to you."

It occurred to James, that if this lady was Princess Myrrh's mother, then she had to be the Queen of Skyaira! And he was in their 'palace'! He could feel the aura of her raw power radiating from her where he was standing, petrified with reverence. Really, he wanted to bow, but his legs were too stiff with anxiety.

And an amazing thing happened! The Great Queen knelt before James, earning a stifled gasp from Myrrh.

"Mother!" Myrrh exclaimed in pure shock. "You bow before an Earth-born? The other pure Misterians will not be happy!"

"You ought to bow too, my daughter," the lady merely replied stiffly.

And in a second, Myrrh was on her knees too. James honestly didn't know what to do. At the moment, he currently had the Great Queen and Princess of Skyaira, bowing before him, claiming that they were in his debt. He flushed with embarrassment. He hadn't even done that much, just knocked out two men and got shot by the third, that's all.

"I didn't do that much," James muttered lamely. "I don't... deserve this..."

The Queen, sensing his discomfort, laughed and rose to her feet. "It was brave of you to risk yourself to protect my daughter. We are forever in your debt. Ask, and it will be granted."

That, only happened in fairytales. James stared at her dumbfounded, before the reality of that statement hit him like a ton of bricks. And immediately, he already knew what he truly wanted. He was sure of it.

Not anything cliche. Not gold, or silver, or bronze. "I want to go to Earth," he said without hesitation. "I want to say farewell to all my loved ones there for the last time."

"That..." the Queen trailed off and shared an uncertain look with her daughter.

"You have to understand," Myrrh said. "We Misterians live by very strict laws."

The Queen nodded sadly. "Earth... is not desirable to us, Misterians. There are only two rigid ways one can gain access there."

"Quests or Tests," James remembered, echoing Myrrh's words. "I understand. And I would like to participate in a Test then."

Silence. From the looks on his companions faces, it seemed as though James had just requested for a death sentence. Myrrh had buried her face into her hands in complete dismay.

"I see your determination," the Queen finally whispered. "Very well then. As Misterians, we value honour. We do not take to unfulfilled debts. So in return, I shall ensure that you are well trained for it at the very least."

"Thank you, My Queen," James smiled, hope spreading throughout him like wildfire. "It means more to me... than anything."

"Do not thank me, brave one." The Queen looked to her daughter. "Myrrh," she said, and Myrrh seemed to understand what she wanted. The girl grinned at her mother before nodding a curt nod towards him. Uh oh, that was the sort of look Nate had when he had just finished pranking some poor first year by the lockers. Not good news.

Without warning, Myrrh had grabbed James by the hand roughly, and was running. Running so fast that the world passed by in a blur. James screamed and squeezed his eyes shut. And despite the blindness, he felt the sensation of a soaring jump, and the realization that he was amid the freedom of the air. He was...

James opened his eyes to find himself off the so called the invisible supposed 'solid floor' by like... a few hundred kilometres. It was freaky. Yes, he had dreamt of flying many times, but when he said 'flying', he meant flying in a vehicle like an aeroplane or something, not being dragged by some crazy girl with wings through the air.

"WHAT THE HELL?" James yelled over the raging winds. "PUT ME DOWN!"

"Hell?" Myrrh asked confused.

"JUST BLOODY PUT ME DOWN!"

Realization dawned on Myrrh. And she giggled. "As a Misterian, you have to get used to this sensation."

"WHAT THE-" a gust of wind cut the curse off in mid sentence. "I wish I were human then!"

James must have said the wrong thing, for Myrrh's cheerful demeanor deteriorated fast.

"Which reminds me," Myrrh's face darkened. "I eluded it earlier... You may not like it... but I decided I must share this with you."

"YOU CAN TELL ME AFTER YOU PUT ME DOWN!" James screeched as Myrrh narrowly missed a couple of floating objects.

Myrrh ignored him. "Earth-borns... are mostly discriminated here..." she said quietly. "That is why your outright request to return to Earth just now... just do not do it in public."

"Discriminated?" James panted, interested. So the Misterians weren't just a whole race of brainless flying creatures. They operated like humans and had the ability to dislike. And they seemed to really really hate humans for some reason. That was news.

"Yes. Humans are pitiful creatures that have so much to learn. Honestly, I used to think that they were flightless demons themselves, only capable of destruction to themselves"

"Holy-" James breathed, suddenly forgetting about his fear of falling or crashing. "Do you... do you believe that?"

"No," Myrrh said. "After you rescued me, -it was an even greater disgrace- but I shall never feel the same about humans again."

For some reason, after hearing about an entire race of pure Misterians who hated him to the core, James just felt better hearing that. "Good," he said gently. "That's all that matters you know."

Myrrh smiled, but the smile faded fast. "Just... watch yourself. Besides being young and inexperienced, Mortal-born Misterians are believed to still have retained a fragment of so called 'earth-weakness' within them. They-... Well, you understand. Careful."

"Thanks."

James gulped, the hopes of visiting his loved ones (humans) on Earth was quickly fading. If they really hated humans that much, would they really allow him to trawl through a human infested area while not on an actual quest? Oh yes, that explained the Tests. They only allowed a small group to go... But even that was pretty lenient.

He suspected with a sinking feeling that the Tests probably were far from easy.

But it didn't matter. He would do anything to see his family and friends one last time.

James wasn't given time to speculate any further, as Myrrh had swept him upwards, high above the clouds, sending him screaming bloody murder as she spiraled gracefully through the skies, lugging him after her. It was only after a moment or so that James realized that despite his denials, he was actually thoroughly enjoying it. Not only that, but he actually wanted to try out flying with his own pair of wings!

"You must learn how to fly," Myrrh was saying in the background. "Misterians look down on those who cannot fly as well and respect those who can."

Really? This was going to be fun.

"Come, let me bring you somewhere," Myrrh abruptly said in mid flight, severing his train of thoughts.

He wondered where to now?
1113.title: The Alternative

11131.content:
"My Princess," the young man across him bowed gracefully. "It is an honour to receive you. And-" He rose once more and coldly studied James. "This is the Earth-Born who rescued you?"

James pursed his lips. For some reason, that man seemed so eager to make an enemy out of him. Yes, yes, he was a- the Earth-born. But not like he asked to be one. In fact, it was ironic, because the only reason he was one was because he sacrificed his life for someone, and left everything else he loved behind.

So this was where bravery got you. Great.

"The one and only," James muttered with contempt.

If the man across heard it, he made no sign. "Doesn't look like much," he commented indifferently.

"Respect him," Myrrh commanded coldly.

The Misterian only bowed curtly once more. "To the best of my ability, Your Highness."

"You will train him," Myrrh said shortly. "Understand?"

"To the best of my ability," the Full-born Misterian repeated reluctantly. "The Queen informed me that he intends to participate in the Tests?"

"Yes," James said firmly, earning a sneer from the man. He ignored the Misterian, before side-glancing Myrrh and mouthing. "So he's my trainer?"

"The very best," Myrrh mouthed back, sighing.

"Oh happy day," James muttered sarcastically. He had a feeling he wasn't going to enjoy training one bit. Why couldn't Myrrh have trained him? Then he remembered the Queen's words: 'I shall ensure that you are well trained for it at the very least', and it struck him that this young-winged-man must be pretty professional then. Besides being a stuck-up git, he must be quite good.

James sized his trainer up. He was attractive- well to be precise, all of them were. He would have been extremely handsome (even for a Misterian) if only his eyes weren't staring at James in such a condescending manner. The Bastard. Seems like that were both Earth and Angelic Bastards.

"So?" James challenged, his previous human self kicking back in. "Bring it on."



"I am assuming you know nothing about flight," his trainer said. And it dawned upon James that it was meant as an insult. He remembered what Myrrh said about the Misterians looking down on those unable to fly.

"Wrong again," James snapped. "I fly as well as an... eagle."

His trainer smirked - not a good one. "Eagles do not fly well," He pointed out. "But go on, let us see if you can even fly as well as a paralyzed eagle."

James bit his lip. Mistake. He liked flying, but couldn't actually fly with his own wings, he realized. Uh oh.

"What a fool" His trainer remarked coldly before shoving him forward.

The floor of the arena underneath him shifted and retracted to the sides, to reveal an an even bigger arena, the floor a thousand feet below him. If you were thinking of some sort of platform, there was none. It wasn't any ordinary arena. But an 'airborne' one; an area soley meant for flight. If one fell from the air, only a thin layer of... CLOUD??? all the way at the very bottom was to catch him.

Also, the arena was pretty crowded with Misterians. If he fell, he would probably crush one of them.

James was sent falling, falling, falling. It took a second or two for him to regain his senses. And another second to spread open his wings. And by the time he managed to actually 'titter' upwards weakly, he was about five feet from hitting the ground head first.

"You could have killed me!" James yelled. "What the bloody-"

"I recall someone boasting about their flying skills."

"Well..." James muttered. "But I didn't expect you to push me off-"

"You're such a fool," His trainer interrupted. "Such cowardice. Truly pitiful."

James felt extremely inclined to give him the finger, but it occurred to him that his trainer's little push had been a blessing disguise. For he was airborne! Airborne and free as the wind!

James was, is, and always would be The King of the Skies. Even a Mysterian couldn't beat him if he tried.

He did the only thing he could think off. "Catch me," James challenged. "If you can!" And with that, he zipped off.

Perhaps his trainer hadn't bothered to give him the chase, because he probably thought it wasn't worth it. But it didn't matter, James was thoroughly enjoying it. That sensation... of the wind against your face; That sensation... of freedom in its purest form.

A dark shape swooped down after him at high speed, and it occurred to James that his trainer had taken up the challenge.

James smirked. He would make that man swallow his insults no matter what.

The shape zoomed to James left, and James ducked and swerved underneath it, narrowly missing a Celestial Pillar.

"You can't ever catch me!" James laughed triumphantly. "Tell you what: I'll catch you!"

And with that, he changed direction without warning, in pursuit of the blur shape before him.

James pushed himself forward.... Nearly, nearly there.... So close that he could picture the man's narrowed eyes, and his look of sheer awe. James smiled, and reached out...

The man dodged, and executed a beautiful, dazzling, amazing ninety-degree plunge in mid-flight. In normal situations, for normal people, they would hesitate, before turning the other way. But for James, he was different. He was the King of the Skies. Without a word, he followed, trying his best to keep control of his wings against the raging wind.

And in this manner, James Walker became the first New Earth-Born in history to complete a Ninety-Degree plunge.

Everyone stopped training in the arena and turned to watch, dumbfounded.

And as the 'cloud-lined' ground drew near, James fought to maintain his balance as he changed direction, gliding forward instead of downwards. The plunge wasn't perfect. His wings felt sore from the pressure, and his thighs from scraping the 'floor', but nonetheless, he was alive.

Or at least he thought he was alive.

James paused to catch his breath, and his instructor landed before him soundlessly.

"Are you... alright?" His instructor whispered in awe.

The adrenalin left James completely. "I... Yes," He replied, before grinning. "Better than ever. Want to try again?"

His instructor just gaped, before holding out his hand. "I am Shadorn, known as Shadow."

"About time you bothered to introduce yourself," James muttered, refusing to take his hand.

The instructor merely shrugged uncaringly. "You have earned a tiny portion of my respect, Young Earth-born. It is your decision to accept it."

"Only a portion?" James asked. "Where's the rest?"

"Only a portion," the instructor agreed firmly, his hand still hanging out loosely.

Hell, James thought. What was with the Misterian's honour, respect, virtues, all that rubbish? Look, he risked his life to perform a ninety degree plunge, and what? He only won a portion of his respect? Who cared for his respect anyway?

The instructor put down his hand. "Alright," James finally decided. "I'll shake your hand."

"Too late," the man replied tautly, before spreading his wings and taking off from the arena. James stared after him smugly before taking off after him, wondering where the instructor would lead him.

"Where are we going?!?!" James yelled after his instructor.

"Never speak while in flight," the instructor scowled at him.

James rolled his eyes. Myrrh never said so. And she was princess. "Tell me where we're going!" James insisted once more.

"Little fo-" The instructor changed the subject realizing that it was no longer applicable. "Little weakling, we are heading to the Weaponry."

"What?"

"You have no longer a need to learn to fly," the full born Misterian forced out, his 'honour' apparently hurt in the process.

"So?"

"So we are moving on to choose your weapon for The Tests," the man snarled back. "Now, shut up."

The Tests... James shivered at that thought. Oh yes, he had yet to sit through that.

And of course, the weapon he were to pick would play an important role. It would determine his win or his loss.

He wondered what weapon would be suitable for someone like him.
11131.title: Training Area

111311.content:
"Here we are," James instructor growled.

As they flew down, James had a few moments to study the weaponry. It was enormous. When they landed, James wanted to ask a question. But one look at the his instructor's face, and James knew that he was not in the mood for questions - as usual. So wordlessly, they went on inside.

"Here, Choose your weapons. I don't have much time," He said, checking his little odd winged watch.

James immediately got down to work and went to search for an weapon. He knew this was important. If he did choose a weapon which he was unable to wield, he would most probably fail the Tests.

The first weapon he came across was a javelin. He knew that throwing was his weakness - he hadn't a single muscle under that shirt of his. So, he simply walked away from it.

He'd started to size up some Misterian-made swords, when he heard the irritating voice of his instructor. " Hurry up! I don't have all day!"

'ARG.' James thought. ' Can his instructor just stop bugging him?'

"Hurry!" The instructor yelled.

James rolled his eyes, but when his Instructor began to stalk off out of impatience - James realized he was serious. James quickly snatched the nearest figthing piece of stick before him before racing after Shadow.

His instructor finally decided to turn. He scoffed for a moment or two, before inspecting the piece of stick that James held in his hand.

"I see," he said solemnly. "A Misterian-made sword?"

James gawked at the stick in his hand. "This is a sword? It doesn't even look like one!"

Shadow scowled. "That, little fool, is one of the greatest Misterian-made swords ever created! I dare say you've just insulted our entire race!" He accused furiously.

James opened his mouth, before closing it without another word. Fine by him. He lifted the 'sword' to inspect it once more. You really couldn't blame him for mistaking it for a stick, because it really did resemble one from all four aspects. James began to wonder if winning was even possible with this thing.

"Follow me," Shadow suddenly commanded coldly.

'What now?' James thought. ' Where are we going?'
111311.title: Misterian-made Sword

1113112.content:
What now?' James thought. 'Where are we going?'... ...

He really could barely hold in his curiosity anymore. His instructor had warned him not to speak while in flight, but James couldn't care less at the moment. So defiantly, he arched forward and shouted, "Hey! Where are we going?"

Shadow scowled at this. At first he refused to answer, but then, after constant bugging, he literally exploded. " You are not supposed talk when you are flying! How many times must I tell you that!?"

James, ignored him - repeating, "Where are we going?"

Shadow looked as if he was about to strangle him there and then, but decided against it.

"We are going to 'The Sharpening'! Now, for the hundredth time, will you shut up!"

It took a long time to reach 'The Sharpening'. But it soon appeared before them. Not as big as the Weaponry of course. But its tip - as though to match its name was carved particularly sharp to resemble a Blade. With one impatient gesture from Shadow, they landed.

"What are we doing here?"

"You are going to sharpen your own sword," he commanded as though it was the most known thing in the world.

"How do you even sharpen a sword?" James asked. It sounded ridiculous. Weren't swords supposed to be sharp in the first place?

Shadow looked insulted at this. "Hand me your Misterian Sword."

James did as he was told, pushing the piece of stick into Shadow's hands. Frankly speaking, he still couldn't believe that was a sword.

Shadow inspected it, twirling it around for eternity, before turning back to face James.

"Take a Sharpener. One of those from the back. And Sharpen it."

James groaned, he didn't like the sound of this. "Help me... please?" He suggested hopefully.

Fat hope. Shadow positively glowered at that request.

"This is a Misterian Practice so I suggest you don't skive of this," Shadow snapped. "A Sword is forever our life-long companion! So upon receiving one, we sharpen it. We shape it to our liking. Its believed that we're shaping our own destiny through this."

The only thing James could think of was, "Oh."

Shadow glared at him. "Would you like me to shape your destiny?"

James wanted to say "I couldn't care less" but he didn't dare to. So instead, he just meekly shook his head in reply.

"Good,"Shadow said.

James went behind and he found lots of ridiculous looking equipment. All of them had different shape and sizes. Most had jagged diamond edges, metallic gears and blades, and others were stuck with pieces of crystal shards. They did not look like sharpeners one bit, but as Shadow mentioned, they had to be. Some looked like broken pencils while others looked like apple slicers. James guessed that the more bizarre The 'Sharpeners' structure, the more extraordinary the result of the 'sword' blade would be.

He decided that he'd go for the coolest looking one.

James went to a corner and picked one up....
1113112.title: The 'Sharpening'

111312.content:
The weaponry was similar to the arena - cylindrical in shape, and spiraling upwards majestically. Only that it was larger, taller, and more beautiful. Once again, it was constructed from silver and glass (possibly the Misterian's favorite materials), but this time, also adorned with Earthly jewels. It seemed that the Misterians certainly had a thing with Human Jewelry. Wow!

Well, but either way, there was no door. Only opened paned windows thousands of feet off the 'ground'.

"How'd we... going to get up there?" James asked curiously.

Shadow stared at him as though James had gone nuts. "Have you forgotten your heritage, young Misterian?" he accused.

"No," James mumbled, feeling sheepish. "Geez, I was only asking a question."

So they flew in. And the moment they landed into its interior, James gasped in shock. For lining the entire level, was just... weapons. Rows and rows of them; shelves after shelves filled with them. Amazing! He had never seen so many weapons in his life!

"This is only one level," Shadow explained arrogantly. "Skyaira is famous for its Weaponry, just as Pandora is known for its Arena."

And then a winged woman appeared. She was middle-aged, with strangely... wise and ancient green eyes. Creepy.

"Ah, my apprentice," She greeted Shadow, before turning to James. "Now... Oh! Isn't this the New Earth-Born who performed a ninety-degree plunge in mid-flight?"

"Yes," Shadow forced out reluctantly. "Nothing great really."

"Nonsense Shadow!" The woman chided him. "He made history!" Then she smiled towards James and James decided that he rather liked her. "What is your name, Great One?"

"James Walker," He replied, before asking. "How did you know that I did the plunge...?"

"Now, now, James," the woman said seriously. "I, Pandora, know many things-"

"Rubbish," Shadow cut in dryly. "I am guessing some nosy parker flew in here to tell you."

With all the activities going on, and when Shadow and Pandora arguing merrily with each other, James found it rather difficult to digest all they said. So, the woman's name was Pandora, named after one of the Misterian cities? And Shadow was her apprentice?

Okay, cool.

"You're Pandora?" James couldn't help but blurt. "Named after one of the Mysterian cities?"

Both Shadow and Pandora looked to each other and laughed. It was the first time James had seen Shadow laugh like this.

"One of the Misterian cities was named after me," Pandora corrected.

"What? Why?"

"She is an old hag for a Misterian," Shadow pointed out critically. Then he turned to Pandora. "I'm guessing next week you're hitting 2900 years?"

"WHAT?" James gasped.

"Manners, my apprentice," Pandora chided. "Well yes, I am that old. And in my lifetime, I dare say I have completed many things."

"She was from Pandora," Shadow added unhelpfully.

"Previously," Pandora agreed. "I was the greatest Quester of all time. Understand why my city - whom prides itself in fighting- was renamed in my honor?"

James felt himself filling up with respect for her upon hearing this. "Wow," he whistled in awe. "You-"

"Back on track!" Shadow scowled. "My apprentice here-" he gestured to James. "Needs a weapon for The Tests. We better hurry up with it."

The woman nodded with agreement before leading them down the aisles and aisles of weapons.

"What sort do you fancy?" She asked James.

"What?"

"You weapon of choice," The woman explained. "Swords?"

"Nah," James decided against it.

"Spears?" she suggested.

James pictured his wimpy self lugging a spear behind him, before shaking it off. "I'll pass, Madam."

Shadow grew impatient. "Tell me," he demanded. "What do you consider yourself skilled at?"

James tried to think of something. He was an awesome computer gamer... An awfully sociable person.... Oh yes! And he was great in the air!

"Like, for example, are you... hard to catch? Hard to find? Slippery? Or strong?" Shadow explained exasperatedly. "Or are you completely useless?"

Pandora kneed her apprentice in the stomach, scowling. "You better leave the talking to me, Shadow."

Throwing a tantrum, Shadow stalked off from his mentor and his apprentice, in search of something better to do. James stared distastefully after him. So that guy had a temper too? He was so unlikable to begin with!

As though reading his thoughts, Pandora patted his shoulder gently. "You are truly lucky, James, to have him as your mentor."

"That's a bad joke," James snapped back.

"No, young one, I am serious." Pandora laughed and continued to lead James down the aisles. "Your mentor is young, yes, but very capable. In fact, I believe you stand a chance of winning the Tests."

"You... Really?" That was a great compliment!

"Just listen to him," Pandora advised. "Block out all the insults, and you will not go wrong."

James didn't know what to say. He didn't agree with her one bit though. "Well.. oh, thank you."

Suddenly, Pandora broke into a grin. After all that serious advice, that was unusual. "Has he shaken your hand yet?"

"Me? He offered..." James grinned back. "But I didn't take it."

"No way!" Pandora burst out laughing. "Even as his mentor, it took me one century to get that handshake! And you rejected it! Oh, oh my!"

James shrugged modestly. "He said I'd only won a tiny portion of his respect. Well, not like I care or anything."

Pandora laughed it off. "Winning his entire respect took me another four centuries! You have a lot of time to impress him, young one!"

James was about to reply when Pandora stopped walking abruptly and entered another small aisle. She reached its end, before pulling out something that resembled two tiny daggers. One black, one white. Something about it was... unsettling. And within the dark aisle, the white one seemed to glow - not a very bright glow, but one of great potential...

"Twin blades," Pandora smiled. "I heard of your dive. True, I have yet to see you fly, but I am guessing it is much beyond average. I think this belongs to you."

"Me...?" James asked in disbelief.

Pandora nodded. "In my early age, I used to adore it. Every time it came to equipping for a Quest, I always used these two."

"They must be ancient!"

"Certainly," Pandora agreed solemnly. "Most Misterians prefer spears and bows and arrows. But spears are conspicuous. You are deft in the air. Remain unseen, and strike from the back with these. That, should be your tactic."

Pandora seemed to be skilled with tactics. But then and again, she had a city renamed after her. She must be amazing!

"Why'd you stop Questing?" James was inclined to know.

Pandora smiled, before gesturing around her. "See this Weaponry?"

"Yep. Why?" Pandora hadn't answered his question yet.

"It's huge isn't it?" James merely nodded, befuddled. "I have lived a long time," Pandora finally explained. "I am one of the few Misterians who know this place inside out. Therefore, is it not befitting for me to be the guide here?"

James blinked. It did make some sense.

"Now, you are done with the equipping procedure," Pandora handed the blades gingerly to James. She then turned before calling out, "Shadow! We are finished!" Before returning her attention to James. "Do me proud, Young One, Apprentice of my Apprentice."

She made it sound like she was his grandmother or something, but James didn't mind.

He wondered what his Mentor had in mind for him next...
111312.title: A Master

choices: Friendly Matches with other Pandora Competitiors
1113122.content:
Shadow had taken one look at the daggers in James hand and nodded in a approval.

"Pandora's Twin Blades," he breathed in awe. "Not a bad choice, Earth-Born."

What? So Shadow was complimenting him and insulting him at the same time? Truly a remarkable feat. "Pandora suggested it," James replied shortly.

Shadow raised his eyebrows. "She... gave it up to you?" he frowned.

"Got a problem?" James questioned defiantly. What was wrong with him?

Shadow shrugged. "Just... unbelievable." Then he looked away, uninterested in the conversation. "Those blades slayed a hundred Demons. Use it well."



After that, Shadow had suggested they head for the Misterian City, Pandora. Remembering Myrrh, James had argued over that decision, but Shadow wasn't hearing anything but his own voice. As far as his Mentor was concerned, his mind was set. He wasn't listening to any Earth-Born's point of view.

"Fine!" James snarled. "You go yourself! I'm staying in Skyaria!"

"You will be seeing your Date again if that is what you are concerned of!" Shadow fought back icily.

"Excuse me?" James asked, aghast. "My Date?"

"The Princess," snapped Shadow.

"You mean Myrrh?" James could feel his wing tips heat up with embarrassment. He didn't bother to argue that he wasn't thinking of her. Because, yes, he was. "Well... Err, no, she isn't... my date. Not like that..."

"Then stop your nonsense!" Shadow bit back. "The Tests are always carried out in Pandora's Arena for it is the grandest of all!"

"So?"

"So, Foolish One," Shadow criticized mercilessly. "You need to familiarize yourself with its layout before The Test, which is next week, on the Eve of the Winter Solstice!"

"Next... week..." James lips felt parched.

Shadow shook his head and sighed for the first time. "You are one of the newest Earth-borns to take the Test. Already a great disadvantage. So we must go, now."

And then the next thing that happened was so unexpected, that James wondered if it was fated. It was too coincidental! For a voice, a most familiar voice which James was overly glad to hear, had called out cheekily from behind them.




"Not thinking of leaving without me, were you?" Myrrh giggled, before landing gracefully beside James. And in her hands, held a tiny sling bag.

"My Princess?" Shadow asked incredulously. "Why...? How...?"

James grinned at Myrrh, more than happy to have her back. "Got the Great Shadow tongue tied, haven't you Myrrh? Amazing!"

Myrrh laughed joyously before glancing at the two in a weird manner. "You two are on nickname basis?"

"Nope, just me!" exclaimed James cheerfully.

Myrrh smiled a stunning smile of amazement at James, and James felt his wingtips reddening again. "Earned his respect, did you not? That is.. amazing. Truthfully speaking, I, even as Princess, haven't. Few have. But I am going to call him Shadow anyway, so too bad!"

"Wait," Shadow lashed out, changing the subject. "Your Highness, how did you know that we are leaving for Pandora earlier...?"

"I talked to Pandora when equipping for a Quest, Shadow," Myrrh explained. "You know Pandora- knows her Apprentice inside out."

"I do not recall telling Pandora anything!" Shadow said angrily, not liking to be read 'inside out'.

Myrrh shrugged. "That is Pandora for you then."

"So you're coming along?" James asked Myrrh happily.

Myrrh nodded firmly. "Definitely. I am in debt to you, and I will go and aid you in whatever way I can."

"So you are basically telling me, My Princess," Shadow demanded. "That you intend to skive off your current Quest, and leave the city of your birth like this?"

"Yes," Myrrh replied stubbornly, chin out. "Why not? I am going."

Shadow muttered something about dishonour. But no one took any notice of that douche bag. James just stood there in disbelief, thanking the stars for his awesome luck. So Myrrh was going along! Yes! Her presence made it seem like a holiday, especially since James had spent the last few hours pathetically, with.... Shadow.



And that was how the unlikely trio came to walk the streets of Pandora half a day later. It turned out that Myrrh's tiny sling bag was 'magic induced', and its interior could store a tremendous amount of things.

"Useful for travel," Myrrh had explained. And James had to agree that it was pretty handy.

But Shadow wasn't sitting around for idle talk. The moment they had touched down in Pandora, he had 'ordered' the Princess Myrrh to reserve a place in the 'Test's Participant's Living Quarters', before dragging James right into Pandora's Arena.

The Arena was as Majestic as Skyaira's Weaponry. Just that it was an Arena. A well maintained one, that was. However, unlike Skyaira's Arena, in Pandora's Arena, there were platforms. Just a couple of them, and floating too. Also, instead of being cylindrical in shape, it was hexagonal in shape.

An unusual sight to behold.

"Sorry," A winged guard stepped right in their path. "The Training Arena has been closed for preparations for the Tests."

Shadow rolled his eyes impatiently, before pointing to James. "He is a participant. We are here to train."

"Participant. Oh, I see. An Earth-Born," and James became an object of close inspection for the guard. The guard seemed to want to make a critical remark about Earth-Borns but decided against it. "So..." He changed the subject. "Where are you two from?"

"Skyaira," James replied.

"Skyaira!" The guard whistled with amazement. "Send my regards to the Queen and the Princess! Say its from Dorinan."

James nodded amiably. "Sure."

"Thank you, Young One!" The guard said gratefully. "You are the first competitor- well, besides our own- to arrive. Wait...- Oh my-"

Suddenly, the Guard took a long look at Shadow. And a look of respect crossed his features. "Shadorn!" He exclaimed. "Youngest Quest Master in history? No way!"

Shadow shrugged humbly, before turning away. So maybe that guy did have a streak of humility in him. James really did wonder what Quest Master was. Obviously, a 'Quester' was someone who participated in Quests. But he had yet to learn the other terms.

"Are you going to let us in?" Shadow asked tautly.

The guard, bowed politely, before showing them the way in. "Yes sir."
1113122.title: To Pandora

11131221.content:
The moment James and Shadow stepped into the Arena, all parrying and thrusting ceased. Misterians gliding above landed on the glass floor immediately. It occurred to James that the Pandorians didn't receive many visitors, hence did not know how to react. Or alternatively, they were surprised that their competitors had arrived this early. It was really hard to tell, because the looks on their faces differed entirely.

"Where're you guys from?" A young boy asked curiously as he landed beside James. It then dawned upon James that this kid's accent was similar to his own. That kid was Earth-Born, and from his region too!

"Skyaira," Shadow replied tightly.

"Skyaira?!?!" The kid exclaimed. "NO WAY!"

James wondered what was there to be excited about. "Yep, we are. Traveled here for The Tests."

The boy instantly swiveled around to face a winged man behind him - his instructor-. "Gorion!" He yelled excitedly. "That's where the Questers go right?"

"Yes," the man replied calmly. "That is the capital city."

"NO WAY!" The boy laughed. "Whoa, you guys are cool! The Queen and Princess lives there! Pandora lives there too, eh? So does Shadorn! Awesome Questers!"

The moment the boy mentioned Shadorn's name, James looked to Shadow in another bout of shock. Shadow looked indifferent as always. But.... Again? Another mention of the Great Shadow! Was he an amazing Quester like his former Mentor, Pandora?

The moment James thought about the elderly Misterian, he began to notice something he hadn't noticed earlier. In the corner of the Arena, stood a colossal statue of a woman with ancient but wise green eyes. Jame's eyes lit up at once. PANDORA! Wasn't that her?

He didn't have to ask, because a winged woman noticed his wide-eyed staring. "That is Pandora," she smiled at him. "The Great Quester in which our city was renamed after."

"Yes," James breathed in awe. "She's... amazing."

"Oh?" The woman raised her eyebrows. "You have met her?"

"In the Skyairan Weaponry," he agreed.

The woman seemed to take that as an insult. "Pandora will always be a Pandorian at heart!" She declared firmly. "Always!"

Shadow rolled his eyes. "Rubbish," he countered. "She has dwelled in Skyaira for many years, and will be there for many years to come."

James didn't understand why Shadow had to make enemies with every single person he met. Honestly, could Shadow even put a nice word and a person's name in one sentence? Perhaps not.

The woman glared at Shadow, before recognition and awe crossed her features. "Shadorn?"

Shadow merely scowled.

The young boy jumped upon hearing that. "SHADORN?" He hollered. "QUEST MASTER?"

"Show some respect, Max," The boy's Mentor told him quietly.

But the boy wasn't listening. Instead, he did the opposite thing. Max scuttled towards Shadow quickly, before practically springing into him, trying to pin Shadow to the floor. Well of course, he failed. Shadow merely flailed for a minute, before throwing him off effortlessly. The only thing the boy succeeded in doing was making him really annoyed.

It was amusing. James grinned.

"What?" Shadow snarled, unamused.

"I want your respect!" The boy proclaimed. And James remembered Shadow offering him his hand - and respect- on the first day.

Shadow turned to his Mentor exasperatedly. "Your Charge is insane! I give no respect to Earth-Borns!"

The man merely grinned back at Shadow slyly.

The boy darted in front of Shadow once more. "They say you give your respect to the very Best! Shake my hand!" He commanded epically.

The winged woman just shook her head and laughed. James couldn't stop himself any longer. Maybe he'd get it from Shadow later, but for now, he was going to enjoy himself. So he joined in the hearty laughter.

The boy tackled Shadow again.

"Get off me!" Shadow gasped, apparently not used to this treatment. He side glanced Max's Mentor urgently. "Tell him to get off me!"

The man's grin broadened. "He will not," he shrugged. "You have to do as he says."

Max was really persistent. He wasn't even close to as good as Shadow was in combating. But he kept on jumping on Shadow. Being as short tempered as Shadow was, he gave in rather quickly. He finally reluctantly decided on offering Max a miserable pinky. Max took it happily anyway.

"One day!" Max declared. "I will have all your respect!"

James was about to tell Max that that would take at least four centuries, but before he could reply, someone slammed a blunt end of a spear into his side.

"What-?" James never finished his sentence as the very same spear flew at him again. He cursed, before dodging in time, the spear millimeters from his head. He didn't think, but just acted instinctively by pulling out the twin blades Pandora had entrusted him with.

The spear hesitated above him. "Pandora's blades?" someone gasped from above.

James finally grasped the opportunity to look at his attacker. It was the same woman who'd pointed Shadow out. What the?

"Yes," he panted in reply.

"You must have been... capable to earn it," she nodded in approval. "Prove it to me." Then she sent her spear flying at his rear end.

James dodged, barely missing it once more. "Hell!" He yelled breathlessly. "I don't wanna fight you!"

"Earn my respect," the woman smiled craftily. "This is the way of the Pandorians."

Hell, James couldn't care less about the way of the Pandorians. But he didn't tell her that. She seemed insulted enough when he'd mentioned Pandoria being in Skyaira. Sensitive. So he just tried to recall Pandoria's wise words as he dodged another thrust.

Oh yes, he had the advantage in the air. The power scale would tip there.

He felt a triumphant smirk form on his features. James spread his silver wings before spiraling up the arena. Unaware of her disadvantage, the woman took off after him confidently.

Free. Adrenalin rushed through his veins.

"Earn my respect!" James echoed back teasingly. "I'll tell you my name!"
11131221.title: Pandorian Honour

111312211.content:
Shadow was craftier than he looked. James bet he had plotted this entirely before they left for Pandora. Because the moment you stepped into Pandora, there was no backing out from challenges. If you a person who couldn't take a fight, best you stay a thousand kilometers away from it. James guessed that it had either something to do with the atmosphere, or Pandora's culture, or the Pandorians nature and belief of respect. You couldn't walk down the road ten meters without getting yourself into a duel.

So James never caught an opportunity to rest. Whenever he secretly snuck out of the Arena to go to the loo or something, some random winged dude would step up to him and request a duel. He just had to hold his bladder. Here, rejecting a duel request was almost as disgracing as failing a Quest.

Everyday, it was just fights after fights after fights. Training, training, training.

And that was where Myrrh came in. She helped loads with his cuts and bruises. She was an awesome Healer.

"I guess I inherited at least one great trait from my Father," Myrrh shrugged. "Healing, I suppose."

"Your father? The King?" James blurted curiously. He hadn't heard a thing of the King.

"My Father, he... He died an unfortunate death."

James didn't know how to react. He just nodded seriously, before reaching forward and resting a single hand on Myrrh's own. "I'm sorry," he said gently.

"It is alright." Myrrh smiled wearily. "He is- was not... Quester material - like me. So... He perished on a Quest."

He did? Then how come no one spoke of the King? There seemed to be no honoury monuments built to commemorate the King!

"I know what you are thinking," she said softly. "He failed a Quest. It is a disgrace. And... he... well, adored humans."

Curiosity got the better of James. "Who- I mean, what, killed him?"

"Demons." Myrrh's eyes immediately turned as frosty as the winter ice. "Flightless, honourless Demons."

Myrrh's scathing remark hung in the air, cutting out the following silence. No words were spoken afterwards. James sensed that Myrrh valued this space and gave her all she needed. Both of them sat in silence as Jame's bruises and cuts smoothed over and regained its healthy colour. As for the deeper ones, Myrrh improved its situation with a little with magic, before patching up the unhealed areas with a bandage.

"Good as new," Myrrh beamed. "How are you feeling?"

"Awesome!" James laughed before standing to his feet, testing out his seemingly new pair of limbs. "Myrrh! Oh Gosh! Thank you!"

"Kill the Demons for me."

She just stared back at him and smiled. James just stood there, fighting the urge to give her one big comforting hug. But when her thoughtful gaze grew pretty awkward, he headed on outside instead.



Max tackled James as soon as he re-entered the Pandorian Arena.

"Dude!" James groaned. "Get off me!"

Max flipped over and somersaulted coolly to his feet. "Hey," he greeted finally. "Haven't earned your respect, have I?"

"Okay, okay," James snapped. "You have my respect!"

Max's eyes bulged out from their sockets. And suddenly, James was worried it was a symptom of an upcoming seizure or something. It was only when five seconds later, Max still hadn't got into a fit yet, and was still staring gapingly at James, did James realize that it wasn't.

"What?" James demanded.

"You can't do that!" Max screeched, prodding James with the blunt edge of his sword. "FIGHT! You've to fight!"

James rolled his eyes. "Who says?"

"I say!" Max chortled proudly. "Everyone says! So-"

Shadow stepped in before Max completed his sentence. He pointed rudely towards James. "You," he demanded. "How are you doing?"

"I, have a name," James scowled.

Shadow cocked his head. "Really? Do prove it."

James bit his lip. From the amused expression Shadow was giving him, James understood what he was getting at. Though unsaid, he was pressing for another bout of intense torture training, making use of the Pandorian Honour to do it. That sly bastard.

Beside Shadow, Max was busy considering whether to pounce on the Great Shadorn once more.

"Alright," Max said thoughtfully. "Prove to me you can beat Shadorn!"

"No one asked for your opinion, Earth-Born," Shadow sniffed.

Max glared at Shadorn. "You know what dude?" he addressed James. "I'm definitely rooting for you now."

James grinned at this. So he had a supporter now. Awesome. "I betcha you won't be disappointed." And with his twin blades at hand, James took off into the air merrily.



The other competitors started streaming in at about noon time. Max was still hanging around James of course, bugging the hell out of him about respect. So what? He had done some major damage to Shadow during the duel, but not like he'd won or anything. No biggie.

"You're damn fast!" Max was exclaiming. "D' you have wings on your feet?"

"Nope," James replied sarcastically. "But I've toes."

"And I heard you beat Karie too! Damn good!"

James thought back about the first challenge he'd taken up- I mean, had been forced to take up in Pandoria. He recalled with a certain nostalgia the tough woman who'd been so intent with spearing him through with a spear on his first day. Oh yes, that was Karie. Sure brought back fond memories.

"Do you know you're damn fast?" Max was repeating again.

James shrugged modestly. "But I ain't as good with the weapons."

"Watch and wait," Max warned, a silly lopsided grin forming on his features. "I'M EARNING YOUR RESPECT!"

"I told you, you can have it."

Max frowned, unsure. "No!" He proclaimed insanely. "One day! I'm so gonna beat you! Watch your back!" Pandorians were downright weird. They pounced on you to get your respect, and when you gave it to them, they didn't want it. Wow.

And with that last challenge hanging in the air unaccepted, Max disappeared to go and check out the new arrivals. James decided to follow suit. After all, they were the ones who controlled his chances of winning.



The new arrivals were well-trained in general. Definitely. Well, there were a handful which needed brushing up - and some were pretty sucky. But on a whole, James was in deep deep trouble. He'd seen the big guy with the massive trident spearing ten dummies through at one go; he'd seen the girl with the sword sparring deftly with Karie; he hadn't seen the kid with the dark wings camouflaging himself. O_Olll. Uh-oh.

"Tomorrow," Shadow said grimly. "- which is two days before The Tests. The challenge will be revealed."

James shivered. "I..."

Shadow shook him violently. "Have more confidence James!" -he had used his name!- "You are acting like a complete Earth-Born!"

"Shut up!" He growled at Shadow.

Shadow rolled his eyes. "You," he forced out stiffly. "Are the fastest Misterian I have ever seen."

A compliment!?! - What was more shocking was that it was- From Shadow? NO WAY!

James grinned. "Oh, you admit it at last."

Shadow bit his lip, his pride apparently very hurt. "Do not get overly proud yet," He snapped back. "Win the Tests, and I may offer the undeserving you, another half of my respect."

James wanted to point out sharply that he couldn't care less, but his thoughts had drifted off to somewhere else. Shadow had mentioned that tomorrow, they were revealing the challenge for The Tests.

What would it be?
111312211.title: Continuous Hard Training

1113122111.content:
"... Demons," The Quest Mistress finished. "Demons with wings."

Looking around, James realized that he wasn't the only one on the verge of wetting is pants. Most of the Earth-Borns and their Mentors had turned so white that they'd put paper to shame. Yes, Demons equaled bad. James knew that. Myrrh had nearly died in combat with a wingless Demon.

And now, they were giving the Demon wings.

"One Demon against Two Earth Borns," The next Quest Master spoke. If that was supposed to be an inspirational speech, it failed because no one felt relieved.

With that, leaving the participants convulsing in fear-like fits, the dozen of Quest Masters/Mistresses stalked off the platform emotionlessly - leaving the Mentors to clean up the spilt milk they'd left behind.



This was supposed to be a day of planning strategies for The Tests. Not worrying your butt off- which everyone appeared to be doing at the moment.

"Demons?" Myrrh's eyes widened. "How can they- They can't-?"

Shadow looked grim. He always was grim. But now, he was grimmer than ever.

"Is it bad?" James asked curiously.

"My Father was killed by a Demon!" Myrrh snapped. "I nearly died by the hands of one! And now you? NO!"

"It's a two against one, Myrrh," James tried to console. "Look on the bright side."

Shadow shut both of them up with a single 'stop-your-bloody-nonsense' glare before pointing abruptly to James. "Tell me, James, what exactly are demons?" he demanded as he usually did.

James had no clue. "Err... Evil creatures of the Below which possess humans?"

Shadow cast him a withering glare.

"What?" protested James indignantly.

Myrrh sighed. Realizing that Shadow had relapsed into his temper tantrums once more, it was her turn to take the wheel. "Demons are- I mean, were... Misterians-"

"WHAT?"

"Yes," Myrrh agreed. "A few hundred years ago. A great deal of Misterians from the city Arcadia rebelled and turned against the King..."

"A rebellion?" James asked, shocked.

Shadow nudged him roughly. "Shut up and listen."

Myrrh just ignored Shadow and nodded sadly to James question. "Misterian guards and soldiers equipped with the best weapons were sent to the contain the situation... And the rebels made their last stand in the city Arcadia. Many died, James. That's why Arcadia is... inhabited. Its is a graveyard for the fallen rebels, and a painful reminder to the rest of us to conform."

James jaw dropped.

"And the point is..?" Shadow prompted Myrrh impatiently.

"Oh yes," Myrrh glared at Shadow. "The remaining survivors were stripped of their wings and banished to Earth for all eternity."

"So?" Shadow scowled. "Go on!"

"It was mistake," Myrrh whispered. "Misterians do not take to having their wings torn off. Those survivors, called 'Fallen Angels' were- are bitter. Most of them are insane. And don't forget, they seek revenge on us."

Shadow was about to yell at her to get on, but Myrrh did anyway. "And don't forget, though wingless, their Magic is still intact."

"But they will die off soon, right?" James asked, frightened now.

"Perhaps," Myrrh shrugged. "But they have bred with humans and other races like the Gaians, and the Aquarians. And the new breed detests us equally, mind you. These are what we call 'Demons'."

James didn't dare ask what the 'Gaians' and 'Aquarians' were. Myrrh spoke of the 'Gaians' as if they were some sort of dirt on her shoe. She had pointed the Aquarians out indifferently as well. He had a feeling she didn't really like them.

James shivered, standing there, rock still. Demons- the word drilled itself into his head like a nail. He wondered how anyone could be so bitter as to pass it on generation after generation. But then he remembered the Misterian's strange concept of honour and realized that they never would never stop hating till they tasted revenge.

And James was up against one of them. The Demon would probably party if he managed to kill James.

"Well, at least we got that sorted out," Shadow told James. "Now for the strategy..."

"Strategy?" James gulped.

Shadow nodded impatiently. "It would be better if we knew your teammate."

"Teammate?"

"Didn't you hear the Quest Master!" Shadow growled. "Yes, you have a fellow Earth-Born companion to help."

Oh yes, James thought. Not that helped. It just meant another Misterian was gonna die with him.

"Come on then," Myrrh severed his thoughts. "Let's have a look at The Lists."
1113122111.title: Demons given Wings

11131221111.content:
I"m paired with Karie," James read out, before turning to Myrrh. "What does that mean?"

Myrrh looked oddly dark and surprised at that piece of news. "Karie," She muttered with shock, before repeating the name once more. "Karie?"

Shadow ignored the entire conversation. He'd been throwing a fit ever since the news of the Princess's disappearance had spread all the way to Pandora. It turned out that Myrrh hadn't leaked out a thing out to her Mother, the Queen. And Skyaira was currently in upheaval. As rumours went, Myrrh had been kidnapped by the Gaians during her Quest - or something equally stupid.

Shadow had stomped around, cursed the skies and the ground, before cursing the Princess in every decent way he could manage.

"Insolent fool!" He had snarled. "Of all things- ARG! What if the Queen declares war on the Gaians?"

Myrrh flushed apologetically. "Well...-"

"It'll be your fault!" Shadow accused defiantly. "I say you pick up your wings and fly back this instant!"

"I..." Myrrh side-glanced James - as though begging for permission to stay. "I..." she choked. "I want to stay with him."

Shadow scowled exasperatedly. "At least inform the Queen-"

"I can't!" Myrrh burst out. "She'll send for me to return immediately!"

"You-"

"I'm staying - by the order of your Princess, I'm to stay!" Myrrh declared stubbornly.

James honestly didn't know who to side. Shadow was right for one thing - Myrrh shouldn't have run off like that, but yet, James hadn't dared admit that he did want Myrrh to stay to support him. He truly felt safe around Myrrh. But he wasn't going to let Shadow in on this secret, especially since his mentor already had the wrong idea about them being 'Dates'.

But James couldn't help himself.

"Shadow..." James said hesitantly. "Just one last day- let her stay. It'll barely make a difference."

Shadow had been most upset by that idea, but to their greatest surprise, he had caved in much later on. (By that time, they'd wasted half a day.) And not to forget, Shadow still refused to talk.




"James.. And ah... the Famous Shadorn? And..." The unknown woman turned to Myrrh. "Who's this, may I ask?"

"Aryn," Myrrh quickly replied.

"And I assume you know Karie?" The unknown woman gestured to the other woman beside her. "My apprentice."

Karis tilted her head forward in acknowledgement before casting James a secret wink - which could be considered as flirtatious. Myrrh saw that - and oh boy- she positively glared back at Karie coldly. James was taken aback. Did Myrrh and Karie know each other before hand? The chances were slim, but it did seem that Myrrh didn't like her very much.

"Yeah," James agreed. "I dueled with Karie before."

The woman smiled at that news. "That's great, as - as you probably already know," She reasoned. "You're paired with her for The Tests."

Karie nodded solemnly. "We'll need a great deal of teamwork to bring down that flying Demon."

And then Myrrh said something which caused James to gawk.

"Should not be hard for you," Myrrh seethed abruptly. "Since you are one yourself."

That really surprised James. Karie was a Misterian apparently - with wings and all - so how could Myrrh accuse her of being a Demon! Myrrh was stubborn at times, but never was she unreasonable!

The stinging remark directed at Karie hung in the air, cutting out the silence which followed afterwards. James expected Karie to deny that accusation, or even launch herself at the Princess, but she didn't. In fact, she did the exact opposite.

"Who told you?" Karie asked coolly.

"Pandora."

"Our heroine?" Karie asked quietly. "What would she know?"

"Enough to know that it was your Demonic father who slayed My F- Our King."

James couldn't believe what he was hearing, it just didn't make sense. How could her 'Demonic' father have killed the King, Myrrh's Father? If Karie's Father was a Demon, then shouldn't she be one too? This puzzled him greatly.

Shadow was eavesdropping on the conversation (rather obviously) but he hadn't made any move.

"What do you mean?" James inquired curiously.

Karie's eyes narrowed dangerously. "Precisely, Aryn."

"That famous Demon who took down Our King," Myrrh whispered bitterly. "Oh - he is powerful, yes. We have not managed to lay our hands on him, but we have been tracking him for centuries. So don't you lie Karie, you are his daughter."

Karie paled upon hearing this.

"So it is true?" Myrrh asked audaciously.

At this, Shadow rose to his feet, before pointing an accusing finger at Myrrh. Perhaps he was still mad at her. "Enough," Shadow commanded. "Really, what is past, is past. The point is, she is a Mysterian now."

This shocked James even more. Oh gosh! So he knew too? Great.

"You know about this?" James frowned towards Shadow.

Shadow raised his eyebrows challengingly. "So? Why shouldn't I?"

"He is a Quest Master," The Unknown Woman said with a sigh. "He leads Quests - of course he knows." When Myrrh was about to open her mouth indignantly to retort, the woman just waved her aside. "As Shadorn said: What is past, is past. Let us not dwell on it. I feel we should start planning for tomorrow's Test."

Myrrh nodded slowly, reluctantly. James snuck a peak at her. Myrrh didn't look angry, he began to realize. She looked more shocked and confused. So he did what sixth sense told him to do - he did that a lot as a human-. He reached down, and pulled Myrrh into an endearing embrace.

That ultimately broke the tension. The unknown woman smiled. Karie chortled. And Shadow grinned wickedly. Uh-oh, not good. But James didn't care there and then- maybe he would have to face Shadow's teasing after this, but now, he was enjoying every bit of the hug.
11131221111.title: Karie from Pandora?

111312211111.content:
Karie whispered something to Shadow in his ear, and Shadow nodded stiffly. He wore no expression on his face. He quietly uttered, "Follow me." and took off swiftly. James tried to keep up with great difficulty. His knees were scraped badly and his wings were tired and sore. It seemed like great weights were tied to them and he was gradually being dragged down by it. Moreover, his ears were hurting from the blast of wind screaming into them as he soared in the sky.

After what seemed like an eternity, they finally slowed down and landed in front of a row of grand houses that looked so majestic. It was as though they were taken out of a fairy tale. From afar, they looked like hundreds of rooms connected together. Only when they drew near, did they appreciate the true splendor of the place. It was actually a very large house, with smaller ones annexed to it. The brilliant colors painted on the walls of every individual building were resplendent, dazzling sunlight was bouncing of the pristine glass planes of windows. The place looked magnificent and well maintained. By now, James was exhausted. His legs were like jellyO, he could barely stand. He was aching badly and needed a rest. Karie smiled kindly. "Why don't you have a good rest and sleep? You do look tired." She gestured towards the 'House'. That is the humongous one in the middle that stood out among the rest. He hoped somewhere in there, a comfortable bed awaits although in his state right now, he could fall asleep anywhere. Yes, even standing where he was. With a faint okay, he dragged himself towards the 'House'.

While they were walking towards the house, Mrryh told James, " This is the Living Quarters, also known as Slaba. It is practically lots of dormitories connected together. Shadow will show you the way." 'Oh-no, not that stupid, show-off misterian again' James thought.

" Shadow, show him the way to his dormitory." Mrryh said to him. "James, follow him."

As they stepped into the "House", Shadow instructed James, "Follow me closely. Many misterians had been lost in this place before." "I'm not surprised," James muttered. Shadow did not seem to notice him talking. After a lot of twists, turns and endless flightless of stairs, they finally reached his dormitory. They stood in front of a cherry wood door. On the surface of the door, there was intricate carvings of creatures which James have never seen before. There were also strange characters engraved right above door frame. "Here. This is your dormitory." Shadow said.

James opened the door, walked to his bed and sat down. It was extremely comfortable. Without even realising, he fell into a deep, dreamless sleep.
111312211111.title: Tomorrow- The Tests

1113122111111.content:
James woke up. Not because he was uncomfortable, but because someone dumped a bucket of water-not just water it was a bucket of icy water. "What the bloody-" James sputtered. "James! GET UP!" Shadow yelled. "Dude! Was that necessary?"James sputtered. "No," Shadow admitted. "But I did everything I could to wake you up." James felt like strangling Shadow and stuffing the bucket of water that he just poured on him down his irritating throat except that he was cold, shivering and very wet. He promised himself that he would get revenge on that. Shadow handed him a towel and some fresh clothes, and said "Today is the day of the tests. Follow me." James nodded his head nervously. He wasn't trained or anything yet. And he knew that he would most probably fail.

James followed Shadow out of the room. When he reached out of Slaba, he saw Karie and Mrryh waiting for him. Karie said "Today is the day of the-" "Test. Yes, I have heard that before." James finished. Karie nodded her head. "Are you ready?" James nodded his head. "Good. Let's go." With that, she flew away. James followed her swiftly.

They landed down. James marveled at awe at how majestic the place looked like. It was gigantic and James could tell that it was used for battling. Mighty pillars surrounded the arena and he hoped that it was used to stop pandemonium.

They were then lead to the arena. Large crowds of misterians gathered around the arena. James then realised that he wasn't the only ones who was peeing in his pants. Other people had came to battle, and James could tell that they were much more frightened than him.

Karie told him "We are one of the first. We must not fail." James gulped and asked "Wha-What h-happens to us we fail?" "This isn't a pass or fail test. It is whether you pass or die."
1113122111111.title: New Awakening

11131221112.content:
Max had barreled over before James could even finish his name - which was only one syllable. So that was... fast you could say. One second ago, Max was attempting to tackle his Mentor, Gorian, and the next, he had raced all the way here and switched to taking down James instead.

He was one crazy little kid.

"GET OFF ME!" James recited the words.

"Oh boy," Max sang cheerfully. "I got Speedo as my Teammate!"

James was flattered that Max was referring to him as Speedo, but that didn't stop him from flinging Max to the ground with a thud. His wrestling skills had improved a great deal, really. Must be because Max had been constantly training him unconsciously while pouncing on him.

"You won again," Max acknowledged as a matter-of-factly.

James shook his head modestly. "You're good Max, but just a bit small."

At these words, Max suddenly went all solemn like a judge handing out a death sentence. It was very comical - for the serious look really didn't suit Max.

"Do you think I can still beat the Demons?" Max asked earnestly. He truly wanted to know.

James nodded vigorously. "I'll help you."

"Well, but do you think I'll get chosen?"

James was confused at this. Why did Max want so badly to win? Definitely to go the Earth - just like him. But did Max have a family he loved like mad? Perhaps. If that was the case, James felt inclined to help him for some unknown reason.

"Yes, you will," James declared firmly. "I will make sure."

"You mean it?" Max questioned. And James realized that he'd made an unbreakable promise unknowingly.

James patted Max's head. "Yeah, of course."

Max demeanor changed entirely. He completely switched from prim and proper judge-like Max to Max! James preferred the true Max personality of Max. The serious Max just seemed to contradict all laws of nature.

The kid did a triple punch in the air. "YEAH! Awesome! Cos you know, I was wondering how my sis is doing down there..."

"Your sister?"

"Yep," Max agreed with a sigh. "You know, I usually bring her around the city to search for scraps of food - but I ain't around. So I wonder if she's hungry."

James hadn't the heart to tell Max that there was no way that any human being could survive without food for... more than two weeks. So he had a sister he wanted to visit... And wait, what did he mean to 'search for scraps of food'? Were they... scavengers? One of those homeless children?

He pitied Max.

Max was staring thoughtfully at James. "You know," he finally spoke. "Even if I get down to Earth, I wonder where to find her..."

"Is there a place you often frequent with her last time?" James prompted.

Max nodded sadly. "But it's too cold to visit during Winter. She won't be there."
